content.description: The good hold ripped off several times. It is now a hard crack to climb without using the juggy holds to the right. Beware crumbly holds that may break off. Can climb the crack as best you can using the good holds to the right only if you get desperate, varying difficulty. Can reach the top from a stand off those holds so make what you will of it. Don't want to give it an avoid because there were solid looking holds you could see to the top but it was hard, hard crimps. I'm sure someone could send it up the crack alone. Maybe it should be avoided but with a good landing, it may be worth a try.
content.location: On the same slab as Splits on Grit to the right.

content.description: An ancient, gritty crack that is the perfect height for a boulder problem. Sit start where it feels natural to place your hands. Crux consists of the first few moves working the crack on blank, slabby feet.Stand start is as good or better starting from fairly low feet. Would recommend against starting on the obvious, high foothold. Makes a good eliminate avoiding that foothold.The jugs that stick out from the top may break loose, I don't entirely trust them, particularly the left one. Some of the rock on this slab is crumbly but the crack and the immediate flat jug up top are solid.
content.location: Headed north along the blue trail from where you come onto it past the water tower you will eventually see a talus that lies between some large slabby cliffs and the cliff of the ridge itself. The crack is on the north end of the talus facing south.

content.description: Drop off or downclimb boulder problem part of a cliff slab.
A rounded pillar of rock that stands out as something meant to be climbed.
content.location: On a lower platform still above the cliffs slightly off the blue trail to the west. It is below Fat Slabs.

content.description: Tiny crimp edges in the middle of the face. Move off them straight up the blank face to slopers and topout. Maybe this climb is not independent of the arete to the right. Still, it would be hard to start on those two crimps in the center of the face. Would be curious to see how it goes and what someone would think of the difficulty.
content.location: Two "levels" below the marking the trail boulder.

content.description: A pretty face in a scenic spot. Sit start with arms spread wide on either side of the low block. The lower you start with right hand the harder the first move can be. Compress up on good feet to the corner/edge of the arete. Reach the top and topout.The juggy holds around the corner of the arete are off.
content.location: Below the boulder marking the trail.

content.description: A slab climb with good holds. Start with left hand in the overhead jug slot and right on a good sidepull. Move up the slab slightly to the right and topout. There are a few nice variations using holds to the left.The log makes a good platform to stand on before entering the climb.
content.location: Right off the blue trail above Natural Wonders.

content.description: Sit start on the undercling and arete. Move straight up the face through fingery holds and top out directly above the start.An easier variation takes the left exit through jugs.
content.location: Northern talus, between Slabs On Slabs & Splits On Grit.One of the first slabs at the upper entrance to the northern talus platform area, faces south and slightly west.

content.description: A pillar of stone blocks with juggy holds. Start with right hand on the corner of the waist level horizontal, on an undercling and left hand on the side of the same block. The transition to the jug off the horizontal is the crux with the not so obvious footholds. The low ledge that juts out to the right and the detached blocks to the left are off. Move up the jugs and topout. Makes a good downclimb as well.
content.location: Just north of Fat Slabs on a lower platform.

content.description: Atop the cliffs overlooking God's Country there are a number of boulders and bouldering walls with a very scenic view behind.
